questions.question: In Yerkes' WWI group intelligence testing, what criterion primarily determined assignment to Army Alpha versus Army Beta?
options: Army Alpha was for recruits who could read and write; Army Beta was for recruits who could not
Army Alpha was for physically stronger recruits; Army Beta was for physically weaker recruits
Army Alpha measured fluid intelligence; Army Beta measured crystallised intelligence
Army Alpha was for existing army members; Army Beta was for new recruits
questions.answer: Army Alpha was for recruits who could read and write; Army Beta was for recruits who could not

questions.question: In Roger, Bull and Smith's microanalysis typology, interruptions were classified along which two overarching dimensions?
options: supportive vs intrusive; and same-sex vs mixed-sex dyads
successful vs unsuccessful; and vocal vs silent interruptions
single vs complex; and successful vs unsuccessful
content vs delivery; and sender vs receiver
questions.answer: single vs complex; and successful vs unsuccessful

questions.question: In Milgram's variations summary, which shock level was highlighted as a common stopping point (a "decision point") for many non-compliant participants?
Which limitation of twin studies was explicitly noted as a challenge to interpreting genetic heritability estimates?
options: Monozygotic twins share only 50% of their DNA, so they are not informative
Twin studies cannot be conducted outside laboratory settings
Twin studies avoid environmental confounds entirely by definition
Monozygotic twins are often treated more similarly than dizygotic twins, undermining equal-environment assumptions
questions.answer: Monozygotic twins are often treated more similarly than dizygotic twins, undermining equal-environment assumptions

questions.question: When adapting personality questionnaires cross-culturally, which equivalence criterion concerns whether the same underlying constructs/factor structure generalise (eg whether the same items cluster into the same trait)?
options: Linguistic equivalence
Psychometric equivalence
Psychological/cultural equivalence
Construct equivalence
questions.answer: Construct equivalence

questions.question: In the three-component model of attitudes described, which component is explicitly framed as a readiness to act (even if no behaviour occurs)?
options: Affect
Behaviour
Cognition
Action
questions.answer: Behaviour

questions.question: In the meta-analysis of implicit theories of intelligence and academic performance described, the association was reported as especially evident for subjects emphasising:
options: fine arts and music performance
purely practical everyday skills
social competence and popularity
verbal and quantitative skills (eg English, maths, science)
questions.answer: verbal and quantitative skills (eg English, maths, science)

questions.question: Which design feature of Raven's Progressive Matrices was emphasised as making it especially suitable for cross-cultural assessment?
options: It is delivered as an oral interview so vocabulary can be clarified
It is a nonverbal multiple-choice reasoning test designed to minimise language/cultural confounds
It depends heavily on culturally specific general knowledge
It primarily measures crystallised knowledge acquired through schooling
questions.answer: It is a nonverbal multiple-choice reasoning test designed to minimise language/cultural confounds

questions.question: In the neuro-cultural model's display rules, what term refers to weakening an emotional expression relative to what one feels?
options: Attenuation
Amplification
Substitution
Concealment
questions.answer: Attenuation

questions.question: In De Ruiter, Mitterer and Enfield's turn-end prediction study, which manipulation produced the sharpest drop in participants' ability to predict turn completion?
options: speech content is filtered but intonation is preserved
listening to the original recording
pitch is flattened but lexical content remains intact
both content and intonation are intact but background noise is added
questions.answer: speech content is filtered but intonation is preserved

questions.question: In Bull's analysis of 33 televised interviews with UK party leaders, the mean reply rate was closest to:
Heritage and Greatbatch's analysis of applause in political speeches (as described) examined:
options: 15 party leader speeches only
all 476 speeches from the 1981 conferences of the three main UK political parties
36 Japanese general election speeches
33 interviews with UK party leaders
questions.answer: all 476 speeches from the 1981 conferences of the three main UK political parties

questions.question: In Bull and Feldman's analysis of Japanese general election speeches described, what was a distinctive feature of applause invitations?
options: Implicit rhetorical devices accounted for nearly all applause instances
Cheering replaced applause as the dominant affiliative response
Uninvited applause dominated over invited applause
Explicit invitations accounted for a large majority of applause instances (around 68%)
questions.answer: Explicit invitations accounted for a large majority of applause instances (around 68%)

questions.question: Bull and Wells challenged Atkinson's claim of near-perfect synchrony between completion points and applause. What proportion of applause instances did they report as synchronised in the way Atkinson described?
Bull and Wells identified two main reasons for uninvited applause. Which pair matches the notes?
options: audience boredom and microphone delay
accent divergence and hedging
speaker status and group membership cues
direct response to speech content and misreading of rhetorical devices
questions.answer: direct response to speech content and misreading of rhetorical devices

questions.question: In the emotional Stroop example used as an implicit measure, which outcome is treated as evidence that emotionally salient material is capturing attention?
options: faster naming of the ink colour for threat-related words than neutral words
slower naming of the ink colour (longer pauses) for threat-related words than neutral words
better episodic recall for threat-related words after delay
greater endorsement of threat-related word meanings on self-report scales
questions.answer: slower naming of the ink colour (longer pauses) for threat-related words than neutral words

questions.question: Which of Eysenck's three super-trait scales was noted as having low internal reliability as a scale?
options: Extraversion
Neuroticism
Psychoticism
Honesty-humility
questions.answer: Psychoticism

questions.question: Which questionnaire was explicitly cited as a short self-report inventory measuring honesty-humility, emotionality, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness and openness?
options: HEXACO-60
NEO-PI-R
EPQ-R
MMPI
questions.answer: HEXACO-60

questions.question: In the three-factor locus of control approach used in health psychology (as described), what change is made relative to Rotter's original internal–external continuum?
options: External locus of control is subdivided into chance and powerful others because both relate to health outcomes
Internal locus of control is subdivided into personal and proxy agency because both relate to health outcomes
A new "collective agency" factor replaces external locus of control
The internal factor is removed because it is not predictive of health behaviour
questions.answer: External locus of control is subdivided into chance and powerful others because both relate to health outcomes

questions.question: According to the self-efficacy discussion, individuals high in self-efficacy are more likely to interpret failure as reflecting:
options: low effort
low ability
stable lack of intelligence
bad luck
questions.answer: low effort

questions.question: In the power-matching persuasion study described (communicator power × audience power), what mechanism was offered for why matching increased persuasion?
options: Matching works because sources and audiences share identical political beliefs
High-power audiences prefer warmth cues, and low-power audiences prefer competence cues
Matching works because high-power sources are always more credible regardless of message content
Matching worked because high-power communicators used more competence-focused arguments and low-power communicators used more warmth-focused arguments, aligning with audience priorities
questions.answer: Matching worked because high-power communicators used more competence-focused arguments and low-power communicators used more warmth-focused arguments, aligning with audience priorities

questions.question: In the expertise × attitude-consistency framework described, how are counterattitudinal messages from expert sources typically processed when the audience is motivated?
options: Ignored because experts are seen as self-interested in persuasion
Accepted heuristically because expertise suppresses scrutiny
Processed like non-expert counterattitudinal messages (mostly ignored)
Scrutinised more systematically to better counter the expert's position
questions.answer: Scrutinised more systematically to better counter the expert's position

questions.question: In the anthropomorphism follow-up on corporate response (denial vs apology vs compensation), what pattern was reported for incremental theorists?
options: Denial produced the most positive attitudes because it signalled confidence
Apology backfired more than denial because it highlighted failure
Compensation harmed attitudes because it implied wrongdoing
Denial produced more negative attitudes, whereas apology and compensation improved attitudes
questions.answer: Denial produced more negative attitudes, whereas apology and compensation improved attitudes

questions.question: Which physiological correlate was listed as typical of powerful people (as described in the approach/inhibition theory section)?
options: higher basal cortisol and higher cortisol reactivity to stressors
lower basal cortisol but higher cortisol reactivity to stressors
no consistent differences in cortisol physiology
lower basal cortisol and lower cortisol reactivity to stressors
questions.answer: lower basal cortisol and lower cortisol reactivity to stressors

questions.question: In the dominance–prestige distinction described, prestige refers to deference and respect primarily because the individual is perceived as:
options: able to coerce and impose costs
authorised by a recognised power structure
controlling tangible economic outcomes
an attractive cultural model or coalition partner
questions.answer: an attractive cultural model or coalition partner

questions.question: According to system justification theory (as summarised), system justification is observed most readily:
options: in explicit self-report measures
at an implicit, nonconscious level of awareness
only when surveillance is present
only as a physiological stress response
questions.answer: at an implicit, nonconscious level of awareness

questions.question: Which type of influence was defined as conforming to group norms when membership in that group is important or salient (eg "that's what people like me do")?
options: Referent informational influence
Normative influence
Informational influence
Compliance due to coercion
questions.answer: Referent informational influence

questions.question: In the pluralistic ignorance study on intergroup interactions described, when the other students in the scenario were white, white participants most often attributed the lack of sitting together to:
options: fear of rejection
lack of interest
a rule-based moral norm against intergroup contact
hostility toward the outgroup
questions.answer: lack of interest

questions.question: In the tight vs loose culture distinction described, which pairing best characterises tight cultures?
options: weak norms and high tolerance of deviance
strong norms and high tolerance of deviance
many strong norms and low tolerance of deviance
few norms and low tolerance of deviance
questions.answer: many strong norms and low tolerance of deviance

questions.question: In the study on gossip as a mechanism for enforcing moral norms, traceability increased pro-group contributions primarily when:
options: group gossip tendency was low (traceability alone was sufficient)
group gossip tendency was high, especially when behaviour was traceable
group gossip tendency was low and behaviour was untraceable
traceability reduced contributions because people feared being judged
questions.answer: group gossip tendency was high, especially when behaviour was traceable

questions.question: In the tweet-diffusion work described, increasing the number of moral-emotional words in a tweet tended to:
options: reduce retweets by making content seem too biased
increase retweets (with effects moderated by issue/valence/network factors)
have no relationship with retweet count once topic was controlled
increase retweets only for politically neutral topics
questions.answer: increase retweets (with effects moderated by issue/valence/network factors)

questions.question: In the second "nonconformity signals status" study described (lecturer scenario), nonconformity increased perceived status primarily when:
options: the setting was explicitly low prestige
the context signalled high prestige (eg high-prestige affiliation), amplifying the status signal of nonconformity
participants were described as non-experts in status judgments
the target conformed strongly to expected dress norms
questions.answer: the context signalled high prestige (eg high-prestige affiliation), amplifying the status signal of nonconformity

questions.question: In the Robin Hood effect described, the target was most likely to be afforded power/leadership when:
options: they conformed to the norm while acting selfishly
they violated the norm while acting selfishly
they conformed to the norm while acting prosocially
they violated a norm in a prosocial way (prosocial nonconformity)
questions.answer: they violated a norm in a prosocial way (prosocial nonconformity)

questions.question: Descriptive deviance was defined as:
options: divergence from the average group attitude in a direction consistent with the desirable group attitude
divergence from the average group attitude in a direction inconsistent with the desirable group attitude
any norm violation regardless of its direction relative to group ideals
a failure to conform due to misunderstanding group norms
questions.answer: divergence from the average group attitude in a direction consistent with the desirable group attitude

questions.question: In Moscovici's colour-judgement minority influence work described, what change in minority size produced a large increase in agreement?
options: increasing a consistent minority from 2 to 3 members
increasing a consistent minority from 1 to 2 members
increasing a consistent minority from 10% to 15%
any increase in an inconsistent minority
questions.answer: increasing a consistent minority from 1 to 2 members

questions.question: In Asch's line-judgement conformity studies described, the average conformity rate (in the presence of wrong-answer confederates) was closest to:
Which Milgram manipulation was explicitly listed as increasing disobedience in the variations summary?
options: The experimenter remained physically present and gave consistent prompts
The participant both read the words and administered shocks personally
The learner was distant and never became proximal to the teacher
The experimenter was not physically present in the room
questions.answer: The experimenter was not physically present in the room

questions.question: In the taxonomy of power bases described, which type is defined as the target's belief that the influencer has generally greater expertise and knowledge (not merely more information)?
options: Reward power
Informational power
Referent power
Expert power
questions.answer: Expert power

questions.question: In the dominance–prestige distinction described, dominance refers to deference received primarily because others perceive the individual as able to:
options: be admired as a cultural model and coalition partner
coerce, intimidate, and impose costs and benefits
provide specialised knowledge about a specific topic
occupy an authorised role in a recognised hierarchy
questions.answer: coerce, intimidate, and impose costs and benefits

questions.question: Within the Social Identity Approach (as described), when group boundaries are perceived as permeable, which route to positive distinctiveness is most consistent with that condition?
options: Social competition (ingroup favouritism)
Depersonalisation (loss of individual identity)
Social creativity (reframing group value dimensions)
Individual mobility (changing groups to climb the hierarchy)
questions.answer: Individual mobility (changing groups to climb the hierarchy)

questions.question: In the system-justification evidence summary, increasing political conservatism was associated with which pattern across high-status and low-status groups (especially on implicit measures)?
options: Both high-status and low-status groups showed stronger ingroup favouritism
Both high-status and low-status groups showed stronger outgroup favouritism
High-status groups showed increased ingroup favouritism while low-status groups showed increased outgroup favouritism
No changes in bias patterns were reported as conservatism increased
questions.answer: High-status groups showed increased ingroup favouritism while low-status groups showed increased outgroup favouritism

questions.question: Which description best matches systematic processing in dual-process models of persuasion (as summarised in the notes)?
options: A default, low-effort mode in which argument quality is largely irrelevant
A mode driven primarily by distraction and low cognitive capacity
A form of processing relying on simple heuristics like "the majority rules"
An effortful scrutiny of relevant information in which argument quality matters, producing more enduring attitude change
questions.answer: An effortful scrutiny of relevant information in which argument quality matters, producing more enduring attitude change

questions.question: Which statement about strong brand relationships was explicitly consistent with the notes?
options: They reflect habit only and do not interact with self-concept
They eliminate negative reactions to brand failure by preventing anthropomorphism
They can elicit loyalty beyond habit and can produce feelings of betrayal when the brand falls short of expectations
They depend entirely on the perceived legitimacy of the company's authority
questions.answer: They can elicit loyalty beyond habit and can produce feelings of betrayal when the brand falls short of expectations

questions.question: In cross-cultural personality assessment, which equivalence criterion focuses on whether individual items have similar meaning in terms of real experiences within each culture (beyond literal translation)?
options: Linguistic equivalence
Construct equivalence
Psychometric equivalence
Psychological/cultural equivalence
questions.answer: Psychological/cultural equivalence

questions.question: Among the listed issues with trait approaches, which criticism specifically emphasised that naming factors is shaped by researcher judgement and constrained by language?
options: The approach is too theory-driven and ignores data
The number of factors is always fixed at five across all datasets
Labelling of factors
Trait models uniquely eliminate the need for interpretation
questions.answer: Labelling of factors

questions.question: Which limitation of adoption studies was explicitly noted as potentially blurring the separation between genetic and environmental influences?
options: Adopted children always grow up in identical environments to their biological families
Adoption studies cannot be used to study any psychological trait
Contact between the adopted child and the biological family can blur the gene–environment separation
Adoption studies avoid all prenatal influences by design
questions.answer: Contact between the adopted child and the biological family can blur the gene–environment separation

questions.question: Which framework was described as the dominant, evidence-based psychometric model that underpins how many modern intelligence tests are designed and interpreted?
options: Howard Gardner's Multiple Intelligences theory
Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory
Spearman's two-factor model alone
Thurstone's primary mental abilities model alone
questions.answer: Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory

questions.question: In the example of geographical differences in Big Five traits across the British Isles described, which pattern was reported for Scotland?
options: Agreeableness is lower and neuroticism is higher in Scotland than elsewhere
Both agreeableness and neuroticism are higher in Scotland than elsewhere
Both agreeableness and neuroticism are lower in Scotland than elsewhere
Agreeableness is higher and neuroticism is lower in Scotland than elsewhere
questions.answer: Agreeableness is higher and neuroticism is lower in Scotland than elsewhere

questions.question: According to the intelligence lecture notes, approximately how many people were forcibly sterilised in the USA under eugenic policies during the 20th century (until the 1970s)?
The Flynn effect described in the notes refers to increases in population IQ test scores of roughly:
options: 0.3 IQ points per decade
15 IQ points per decade
3 IQ points per decade
30 IQ points per decade
questions.answer: 3 IQ points per decade
